Spring 2018

Minds at Peace

UX/UI Design

‹Redwood Counseling›Vivacity Healing

Challenge

Minds at Peace was in need of a interface redesign to help attract new clients and keep visitors on the website.

Role

Redesign and declutter the website with intuitive navigation and a simple, calm interface

Overview

Minds at Peace is a local start-up company in Cincinnati that specializes in mindfulness meditation. The owner of Minds at Peace reached out to me for help in designing a clean and friendly interface.

Goals

I approached my design in three steps, while conducting research throughout:

  1. Core experience
  2. Intuitive navigation
  3. Clean visual interface

Inspiration

When I think of meditation, I see beautiful beaches and ocean waves. Mindfulness meditation is a calming experience. Naturally, I felt that a relaxing scenery would suit it best.

These are some examples I gathered during the discovery phase for what I wanted our users to experience.

1. Core experience

Instead of creating the entire brand identity my job here was to create a website that matched the company logo. It was very important for my client that people know they are as Minds at Peace when they entered the site.

My first task was to develop a visually appealing site that is more upbeat and happy. I wanted to create a website that could trigger a positive emotional and intellectual response.

I chose the ocean image for the banners because it represented the Minds at Peace journey of calming and strengthening the mind. The company was needed a fresh look that is clean and simple.

This was the easy part of this project. I then felt overwhelmed with the endless scrolling of unorganized content. I put on my red cape and got to work.

Cluttered websites are visually confusing and the user doesn't know where to direct their attention. My goal here was to create an organized layout while keeping the core idea of the content.

I also felt it was important to showcase the purpose the website serves and make it the focal point of the homepage.

2. Navigation

In this particular project navigation was especially important. My client, Minds at Peace, is passionate about mindfulness meditation which resulted in a lot of information.

So when I started working on this I stepped back and thought,

How can I create a navigation that users can easily find what they are looking for while holding the same information?

Useable, simple, and elegant hierarchy is critical to any website - ours included. To keep it simple, I used one word items rather than dropdown menus.

The main objective for navigation on any website is facilitating solid wayfinding. I like to think of it as a highway sign, navigating options on a site are universal indicators of where to find information and what lies behind the next click.

My goal was to eliminate scrolling as much as I could. Especially as we continue into a mobile world, scannable content is so important.

3. Visual interface

The main complaint I heard about the old interface was that it felt complicated and difficult to operate. For this I wanted to achieve one of the top golden rules for UI design, the 4E’s.

  1. Error-free.
  2. Easy to use.
  3. Easy to understand.
  4. Effective for the end goal or product.

It was essential for the UI design to guide users how to interact with the website in a clear and intuitive way, even for first time users.

The site’s pages consisted of a lot of reading which felt difficult for users to find the key information that they were looking for. We worked to create a simpler way for users to view the services that Minds at Peace offered.

I came up with a way for users to read a brief description about each of the services and a link that could lead them to more information if they desired to read more.

The other aspect of the old interface that was a problem was the consistency. The UI design needed to be consistent on the style in order to make users clearly understand and respond to the content given to them.

Landing page

The old landing page was a very busy hero image with the logo plastered on top. I wanted to achieve a clean and simple look by using the ocean image and a few words to greet our users.

This is great way to represent a business that offers services to calm and strengthen your mind. Now, I believe when first time users step into our site they feel like they are in the right place.

Conclusion

After several late nights and a lot of coffee we achieved our goals for the new site. Woo-hoo!

I wanted to provide Minds at Peace with the professional look it deserved. My client is extremely pleased with the simplicity of the website while achieving all of their goals.

There have been several compliments on the improvements we made and how responsive it is on any device now.

That's a wrap!

You can check out more of my work on Instagram and Dribbble.

Vivacity Healing
